an4.236:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.236:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.236:1.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

an4.236:1.5.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and

an4.236:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.236:1.6.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.236:2.1.eng: And what are dark deeds with dark results?

an4.236:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekaccena mātā jīvitā voropitā hoti, pitā jīvitā voropito hoti, arahaṃ jīvitā voropito hoti, tathāgatassa duṭṭhena cittena lohitaṃ uppāditaṃ hoti, saṅgho bhinno hoti.
an4.236:2.2.eng: It’s when someone murders their mother or father or a perfected one. They maliciously shed the blood of a Realized One. Or they cause a schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.236:2.3.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.236:2.3.eng: These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.236:3.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.236:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti, adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti, kāmesumicchācārā paṭivirato hoti, musāvādā paṭivirato hoti, pisuṇāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, pharusāya vācāya paṭivirato hoti, samphappalāpā paṭivirato hoti, anabhijjhālu hoti, abyāpannacitto hoti, sammādiṭṭhi hoti.
an4.236:3.2.eng: It’s when someone doesn’t kill living creatures, steal, or commit sexual misconduct. They don’t use speech that’s false, divisive, harsh, or nonsensical. And they’re content, kind-hearted, with right view.

an4.236:3.3.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.236:3.3.eng: These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.236:4.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.236:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.236:4.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.236:5.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.236:5.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.236:5.2.pli: Tatra, bhikkhave, yamidaṃ kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.236:5.2.eng: It’s the intention to give up dark deeds with dark results, bright deeds with bright results, and both dark and bright deeds with both dark and bright results. These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.236:5.3.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.236:5.3.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.237:1.1.pli: “Cattārimāni, bhikkhave, kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
an4.237:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight.

an4.237:1.3.eng: There are dark deeds with dark results;

an4.237:1.5.eng: dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results; and

an4.237:1.6.pli: atthi, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.237:1.6.eng: neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.237:2.1.eng: And what are dark deeds with dark results?

an4.237:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.237:2.2.eng: It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.237:3.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.237:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.237:3.2.eng: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.237:4.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.237:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.237:4.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.237:5.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.237:5.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.237:5.2.eng: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.

an4.237:5.3.pli: Idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.237:5.3.eng: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.237:5.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.237:5.4.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.238:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, I declare these four kinds of deeds, having realized them with my own insight….

an4.238:1.2.pli: idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhaṃ kaṇhavipākaṃ.
an4.238:1.2.eng: And what are dark deeds with dark results? It’s when someone makes hurtful choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark deeds with dark results.

an4.238:2.1.eng: And what are bright deeds with bright results?

an4.238:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco abyābajjhaṃ kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ sukkaṃ sukkavipākaṃ.
an4.238:2.2.eng: It’s when someone makes pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called bright deeds with bright results.

an4.238:3.1.eng: And what are dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results?

an4.238:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, ekacco sabyābajjhampi abyābajjhampi kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti …pe… idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ kaṇhasukkaṃ kaṇhasukkavipākaṃ.
an4.238:3.2.eng: It’s when someone makes both hurtful and pleasing choices by way of body, speech, and mind. These are called dark and bright deeds with dark and bright results.

an4.238:4.1.pli: Katamañca, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati?
an4.238:4.1.eng: And what are neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds?

an4.238:4.2.pli: Satisambojjhaṅgo, dhammavicayasambojjhaṅgo, vīriyasambojjhaṅgo, pītisambojjhaṅgo, passaddhisambojjhaṅgo, samādhisambojjhaṅgo, upekkhāsambojjhaṅgo—
an4.238:4.2.eng: The awakening factors of mindfulness, investigation of principles, energy, rapture, tranquility, immersion, and equanimity.

an4.238:4.3.pli: idaṃ vuccati, bhikkhave, kammaṃ akaṇhaasukkaṃ akaṇhaasukkavipākaṃ kammakkhayāya saṃvattati.
an4.238:4.3.eng: These are called neither dark nor bright deeds with neither dark nor bright results, which lead to the ending of deeds.

an4.238:4.4.pli: Imāni kho, bhikkhave, cattāri kammāni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditānī”ti.
an4.238:4.4.eng: These are the four kinds of deeds that I declare, having realized them with my own insight.”

an4.239:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.239:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, someone with four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.239:1.3.pli: Sāvajjena kāyakammena, sāvajjena vacīkammena, sāvajjena manokammena, sāvajjāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.239:1.3.eng: Blameworthy deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and blameworthy view.

an4.239:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.239:1.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.239:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an4.239:2.1.eng: Someone with four qualities is raised up to heaven.

an4.239:2.3.pli: Anavajjena kāyakammena, anavajjena vacīkammena, anavajjena manokammena, anavajjāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.239:2.3.eng: Blameless deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and blameless view.

an4.239:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an4.239:2.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an4.24:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sākete viharati kāḷakārāme.
an4.24:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa, in Kāḷaka’s monastery.

an4.24:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

an4.24:2.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ jānāmi.
an4.24:2.1.eng: “In this world—with its gods, Māras, and divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: that I know.

an4.24:3.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ abbhaññāsiṃ.
an4.24:3.1.eng: In this world—with its gods, Māras, and Divinities, this population with its ascetics and brahmins, its gods and humans—whatever is seen, heard, thought, known, attained, sought, and explored by the mind: that I have insight into.

an4.24:3.2.pli: Taṃ tathāgatassa viditaṃ, taṃ tathāgato na upaṭṭhāsi.
an4.24:3.2.eng: That has been known by a Realized One, but a Realized One is not subject to it.

an4.24:4.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, sadevakassa lokassa samārakassa sabrahmakassa sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiyā pajāya sadevamanussāya diṭṭhaṃ sutaṃ mutaṃ viññātaṃ pattaṃ pariyesitaṃ anuvicaritaṃ manasā, tamahaṃ na jānāmīti vadeyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa musā.
an4.24:4.1.eng: If I were to say that ‘I do not know … the world with its gods’, I would be lying.

an4.24:5.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave …pe… tamahaṃ jānāmi ca na ca jānāmīti vadeyyaṃ, tampassa tādisameva.
an4.24:5.1.eng: If I were to say that ‘I both know and do not know … the world with its gods’, that would be just the same.

an4.24:6.1.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave …pe… tamahaṃ neva jānāmi na na jānāmīti vadeyyaṃ, taṃ mamassa kali.
an4.24:6.1.eng: If I were to say that ‘I neither know nor do not know … the world with its gods’, that would be my fault.

an4.24:7.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato daṭṭhā daṭṭhabbaṃ, diṭṭhaṃ na maññati, adiṭṭhaṃ na maññati, daṭṭhabbaṃ na maññati, daṭṭhāraṃ na maññati;
an4.24:7.1.eng: So a Realized One sees what is to be seen, but does not conceive what is seen, does not conceive what is unseen, does not conceive what is to be seen, and does not conceive a seer.

an4.24:7.2.pli: sutvā sotabbaṃ, sutaṃ na maññati, asutaṃ na maññati, sotabbaṃ na maññati, sotāraṃ na maññati;
an4.24:7.2.eng: He hears what is to be heard, but does not conceive what is heard, does not conceive what is unheard, does not conceive what is to be heard, and does not conceive a hearer.

an4.24:7.3.pli: mutvā motabbaṃ, mutaṃ na maññati, amutaṃ na maññati, motabbaṃ na maññati, motāraṃ na maññati;
an4.24:7.3.eng: He thinks what is to be thought, but does not conceive what is thought, does not conceive what is not thought, does not conceive what is to be thought, and does not conceive a thinker.

an4.24:7.4.pli: viññatvā viññātabbaṃ, viññātaṃ na maññati, aviññātaṃ na maññati, viññātabbaṃ na maññati, viññātāraṃ na maññati.
an4.24:7.4.eng: He knows what is to be known, but does not conceive what is known, does not conceive what is unknown, does not conceive what is to be known, and does not conceive a knower.

an4.24:7.5.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, tathāgato diṭṭhasutamutaviññātabbesu dhammesu tādīyeva tādī.
an4.24:7.5.eng: Since a Realized One is unaffected in the midst of things that ought be seen, heard, thought, and known, he is the unaffected one.

an4.24:7.6.pli: ‘Tamhā ca pana tādimhā añño tādī uttaritaro vā paṇītataro vā natthī’ti vadāmīti.
an4.24:7.6.eng: And I say that there is no better or finer poise than this.

an4.24:8.1.pli: Yaṃ kiñci diṭṭhaṃva sutaṃ mutaṃ vā,
an4.24:8.1.eng: Such a one does not take anything

an4.24:8.2.eng: seen, heard, or thought to be ultimately true or false.

an4.24:8.3.eng: But others get attached, thinking it’s the truth,

an4.24:9.2.eng: to which people are attached and cling,

an4.24:9.3.eng: saying, ‘I know, I see, that’s how it is’,

an4.24:9.4.eng: the Realized Ones have no attachments.”

an4.240:1.1.pli: “Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.240:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, someone with four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.240:1.3.pli: Sabyābajjhena kāyakammena, sabyābajjhena vacīkammena, sabyābajjhena manokammena, sabyābajjhāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.240:1.3.eng: Hurtful deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and hurtful view.

an4.240:1.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ niraye.
an4.240:1.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is cast down to hell.

an4.240:2.1.pli: Catūhi, bhikkhave, dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge.
an4.240:2.1.eng: Someone with four qualities is raised up to heaven.

an4.240:2.3.pli: Abyābajjhena kāyakammena, abyābajjhena vacīkammena, abyābajjhena manokammena, abyābajjhāya diṭṭhiyā—
an4.240:2.3.eng: Pleasing deeds by way of body, speech, and mind, and pleasing view.

an4.240:2.4.pli: imehi kho, bhikkhave, catūhi dhammehi samannāgato yathābhataṃ nikkhitto evaṃ sagge”ti.
an4.240:2.4.eng: Someone with these four qualities is raised up to heaven.”

an4.241:1.1.pli: “‘Idheva, bhikkhave, paṭhamo samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;
an4.241:1.1.eng: “‘Only here is there a first ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.

an4.241:1.2.eng: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’

an4.241:1.3.eng: This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.

an4.241:2.1.eng: And who is the first ascetic?

an4.241:2.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā sotāpanno hoti avinipātadhammo niyato sambodhiparāyaṇo.
an4.241:2.2.eng: It’s a mendicant who—with the ending of three fetters—is a stream-enterer, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.

an4.241:3.1.eng: And who is the second ascetic?

an4.241:3.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu tiṇṇaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā rāgadosamohānaṃ tanuttā sakadāgāmī hoti, sakideva imaṃ lokaṃ āgantvā dukkhassantaṃ karoti.
an4.241:3.2.eng: It’s a mendicant who—with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion—is a once-returner. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.

an4.241:4.1.eng: And who is the third ascetic?

an4.241:4.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu pañcannaṃ orambhāgiyānaṃ saṃyojanānaṃ parikkhayā opapātiko hoti tattha parinibbāyī anāvattidhammo tasmā lokā.
an4.241:4.2.eng: It’s a mendicant who—with the ending of the five lower fetters—is reborn spontaneously. They’re extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.

an4.241:5.1.eng: And who is the fourth ascetic?

an4.241:5.2.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu āsavānaṃ khayā anāsavaṃ cetovimuttiṃ paññāvimuttiṃ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
an4.241:5.2.eng: It’s a mendicant who realizes the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.

an4.241:6.1.pli: ‘Idheva, bhikkhave, paṭhamo samaṇo, idha dutiyo samaṇo, idha tatiyo samaṇo, idha catuttho samaṇo;
an4.241:6.1.eng: ‘Only here is there a first ascetic, here a second ascetic, here a third ascetic, and here a fourth ascetic.

an4.241:6.2.eng: Other sects are empty of ascetics.’

an4.241:6.3.eng: This, mendicants, is how you should rightly roar your lion’s roar.”

an4.242:0.3.eng: Benefits of Relying on a True Person

an4.242:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, you can expect four benefits from relying on a true person.

an4.242:1.3.pli: Ariyena sīlena vaḍḍhati, ariyena samādhinā vaḍḍhati, ariyāya paññāya vaḍḍhati, ariyāya vimuttiyā vaḍḍhati—
an4.242:1.3.eng: Growth in noble ethics, immersion, wisdom, and freedom.

an4.242:1.4.pli: sappurisaṃ, bhikkhave, nissāya ime cattāro ānisaṃsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
an4.242:1.4.eng: You can expect these four benefits from relying on a true person.”

an4.243:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
an4.243:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

an4.243:1.2.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ ānandaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.243:1.2.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,

an4.243:1.3.eng: “Well, Ānanda, has that disciplinary issue been settled yet?”

an4.243:1.5.pli: Āyasmato, bhante, anuruddhassa bāhiyo nāma saddhivihāriko kevalakappaṃ saṅghabhedāya ṭhito.
an4.243:1.5.eng: Venerable Anuruddha’s protégé Bāhiya remains entirely committed to creating a schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:1.6.pli: Tatrāyasmā anuruddho na ekavācikampi bhaṇitabbaṃ maññatī”ti.
an4.243:1.6.eng: But Anuruddha doesn’t think to say a single word about it.”

an4.243:2.1.eng: “But Ānanda, since when has Anuruddha been involved in disciplinary issues in the midst of the Saṅgha?

an4.243:2.2.pli: Nanu, ānanda, yāni kānici adhikaraṇāni uppajjanti, sabbāni tāni tumhe ceva vūpasametha sāriputtamoggallānā ca.
an4.243:2.2.eng: Shouldn’t you, together with Sāriputta and Moggallāna, settle all disciplinary issues that come up?

an4.243:3.1.pli: Cattārome, ānanda, atthavase sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandati.
an4.243:3.1.eng: A bad monk sees four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:3.3.pli: Idhānanda, pāpabhikkhu dussīlo hoti pāpadhammo asuci saṅkassarasamācāro paṭicchannakammanto assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño antopūti avassuto kasambujāto.
an4.243:3.3.eng: Take an unethical monk, of bad qualities, filthy, with suspicious behavior, underhand, no true ascetic or spiritual practitioner—though claiming to be one—rotten inside, festering, and depraved.

an4.243:3.5.eng: ‘Suppose the monks know that I’m a bad monk …

an4.243:3.6.pli: dussīlo pāpadhammo asuci saṅkassarasamācāro paṭicchannakammanto assamaṇo samaṇapaṭiñño abrahmacārī brahmacāripaṭiñño antopūti avassuto kasambujātoti, samaggā maṃ santā nāsessanti;
an4.243:3.6.eng: If they’re in harmony, they’ll expel me,

an4.243:3.7.eng: but if they’re divided they won’t.’

an4.243:3.8.pli: Idaṃ, ānanda, paṭhamaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandati.
an4.243:3.8.eng: A bad monk sees this as the first reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:4.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, pāpabhikkhu micchādiṭṭhiko hoti, antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgato.
an4.243:4.1.eng: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong view, he’s attached to an extremist view.

an4.243:4.3.eng: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong view …

an4.243:4.4.pli: micchādiṭṭhiko antaggāhikāya diṭṭhiyā samannāgatoti, samaggā maṃ santā nāsessanti;
an4.243:4.4.eng: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,

an4.243:4.5.eng: but if they’re divided they won’t.’

an4.243:4.6.pli: Idaṃ, ānanda, dutiyaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandati.
an4.243:4.6.eng: A bad monk sees this as the second reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:5.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, pāpabhikkhu micchāājīvo hoti, micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappeti.
an4.243:5.1.eng: Furthermore, a bad monk has wrong livelihood and earns a living by wrong livelihood.

an4.243:5.3.eng: ‘Suppose the monks know that I have wrong livelihood …

an4.243:5.4.pli: micchāājīvo micchāājīvena jīvikaṃ kappetīti, samaggā maṃ santā nāsessanti;
an4.243:5.4.eng: If they’re in harmony they’ll expel me,

an4.243:5.5.eng: but if they’re divided they won’t.’

an4.243:5.6.pli: Idaṃ, ānanda, tatiyaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandati.
an4.243:5.6.eng: A bad monk sees this as the third reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:6.1.pli: Puna caparaṃ, ānanda, pāpabhikkhu lābhakāmo hoti sakkārakāmo anavaññattikāmo.
an4.243:6.1.eng: Furthermore, a bad monk desires material things, honor, and admiration.

an4.243:6.3.eng: ‘Suppose the monks know that I desire material things, honor, and admiration.

an4.243:6.4.pli: lābhakāmo sakkārakāmo anavaññattikāmoti, samaggā maṃ santā na sakkarissanti na garuṃ karissanti na mānessanti na pūjessanti;
an4.243:6.4.eng: If they’re in harmony they won’t honor, respect, revere, or venerate me,

an4.243:6.5.pli: vaggā pana maṃ sakkarissanti garuṃ karissanti mānessanti pūjessantī’ti.
an4.243:6.5.eng: but if they’re divided they will.’

an4.243:6.6.pli: Idaṃ, ānanda, catutthaṃ atthavasaṃ sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandati.
an4.243:6.6.eng: A bad monk sees this as the fourth reason to relish schism in the Saṅgha.

an4.243:6.7.pli: Ime kho, ānanda, cattāro atthavase sampassamāno pāpabhikkhu saṅghabhedena nandatī”ti.
an4.243:6.7.eng: A bad monk sees these four reasons to relish schism in the Saṅgha.”

an4.244:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are these four perils of offenses.

an4.244:1.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, coraṃ āgucāriṃ gahetvā rañño dasseyyuṃ:
an4.244:1.3.eng: Suppose they were to arrest a bandit, a criminal and present him to the king, saying:

an4.244:1.4.eng: ‘Your Majesty, this is a bandit, a criminal.

an4.244:1.7.pli: ‘gacchatha, bho, imaṃ purisaṃ daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṃ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sīsaṃ chindathā’ti.
an4.244:1.7.eng: ‘Go, my men, and tie this man’s arms tightly behind his back with a strong rope. Shave his head and march him from street to street and square to square to the beating of a harsh drum. Then take him out the south gate and there, to the south of the city, chop off his head.’

an4.244:1.8.pli: Tamenaṃ rañño purisā daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṃ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sīsaṃ chindeyyuṃ.
an4.244:1.8.eng: The king’s men would do as they were told.

an4.244:1.10.pli: ‘pāpakaṃ vata, bho, ayaṃ puriso kammaṃ akāsi gārayhaṃ sīsacchejjaṃ.
an4.244:1.10.eng: ‘This man must have done a truly bad and reprehensible deed, a capital offense.

an4.244:1.11.pli: Yatra hi nāma rañño purisā daḷhāya rajjuyā pacchābāhaṃ gāḷhabandhanaṃ bandhitvā khuramuṇḍaṃ karitvā kharassarena paṇavena rathikāya rathikaṃ siṅghāṭakena siṅghāṭakaṃ parinetvā dakkhiṇena dvārena nikkhāmetvā dakkhiṇato nagarassa sīsaṃ chindissanti.

an4.244:1.12.pli: So vatassāhaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ na kareyyaṃ gārayhaṃ sīsacchejjan’ti.
an4.244:1.12.eng: There’s no way I’d ever do such a bad and reprehensible deed, a capital offense.’

an4.244:1.13.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā evaṃ tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti pārājikesu dhammesu.
an4.244:1.13.eng: In the same way, take any monk or nun who has set up such an acute perception of peril regarding expulsion offenses.

an4.244:1.14.pli: Tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—anāpanno vā pārājikaṃ dhammaṃ na āpajjissati, āpanno vā pārājikaṃ dhammaṃ yathādhammaṃ paṭikarissati.
an4.244:1.14.eng: It can be expected that if they haven’t committed an expulsion offense they won’t, and if they committed one they will deal with it properly.

an4.244:2.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā musalaṃ khandhe āropetvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya:
an4.244:2.1.eng: Suppose a man was to put on a black cloth, mess up his hair, and put a club on his shoulder. Then he approaches a large crowd and says:

an4.244:2.2.pli: ‘ahaṃ, bhante, pāpakammaṃ akāsiṃ gārayhaṃ mosallaṃ, yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī’ti.
an4.244:2.2.eng: ‘Sirs, I’ve done a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of clubbing. I submit to your pleasure.’

an4.244:2.4.pli: ‘pāpakaṃ vata, bho, ayaṃ puriso kammaṃ akāsi gārayhaṃ mosallaṃ.
an4.244:2.4.eng: ‘This man must have done a truly bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of clubbing. …

an4.244:2.5.pli: Yatra hi nāma kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā musalaṃ khandhe āropetvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhati:

an4.244:2.6.pli: “ahaṃ, bhante, pāpakammaṃ akāsiṃ gārayhaṃ mosallaṃ, yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī”ti.

an4.244:2.7.pli: So vatassāhaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ na kareyyaṃ gārayhaṃ mosallan’ti.
an4.244:2.7.eng: There’s no way I’d ever do such a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of clubbing.’

an4.244:2.8.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā evaṃ tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti saṅghādisesesu dhammesu, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—anāpanno vā saṅghādisesaṃ dhammaṃ na āpajjissati, āpanno vā saṅghādisesaṃ dhammaṃ yathādhammaṃ paṭikarissati.
an4.244:2.8.eng: In the same way, take any monk or nun who has set up such an acute perception of peril regarding suspension offenses. It can be expected that if they haven’t committed a suspension offense they won’t, and if they committed one they will deal with it properly.

an4.244:3.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā bhasmapuṭaṃ khandhe āropetvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya:
an4.244:3.1.eng: Suppose a man was to put on a black cloth, mess up his hair, and put a sack of ashes on his shoulder. Then he approaches a large crowd and says:

an4.244:3.2.eng: ‘Sirs, I’ve done a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of a sack of ashes.

an4.244:3.3.pli: Yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī’ti.

an4.244:3.5.pli: ‘pāpakaṃ vata, bho, ayaṃ puriso kammaṃ akāsi gārayhaṃ bhasmapuṭaṃ.
an4.244:3.5.eng: ‘This man must have done a truly bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of a sack of ashes. …

an4.244:3.6.pli: Yatra hi nāma kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā bhasmapuṭaṃ khandhe āropetvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhati:

an4.244:3.8.pli: yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī”ti.

an4.244:3.9.pli: So vatassāhaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ na kareyyaṃ gārayhaṃ bhasmapuṭan’ti.
an4.244:3.9.eng: There’s no way I’d ever do such a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of a sack of ashes.’

an4.244:3.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā evaṃ tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti pācittiyesu dhammesu, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—anāpanno vā pācittiyaṃ dhammaṃ na āpajjissati, āpanno vā pācittiyaṃ dhammaṃ yathādhammaṃ paṭikarissati.
an4.244:3.10.eng: In the same way, take any monk or nun who has set up such an acute perception of peril regarding confessable offenses. It can be expected that if they haven’t committed a confessable offense they won’t, and if they committed one they will deal with it properly.

an4.244:4.1.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vadeyya:
an4.244:4.1.eng: Suppose a man was to put on a black cloth and mess up his hair. Then he approaches a large crowd and says:

an4.244:4.2.eng: ‘Sirs, I’ve done a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of criticism.

an4.244:4.3.pli: Yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī’ti.

an4.244:4.5.pli: ‘pāpakaṃ vata, bho, ayaṃ puriso kammaṃ akāsi gārayhaṃ upavajjaṃ.
an4.244:4.5.eng: ‘This man must have done a truly bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of criticism. …

an4.244:4.6.pli: Yatra hi nāma kāḷavatthaṃ paridhāya kese pakiritvā mahājanakāyaṃ upasaṅkamitvā evaṃ vakkhati:

an4.244:4.8.pli: yena me āyasmanto attamanā honti taṃ karomī”ti.

an4.244:4.9.pli: So vatassāhaṃ evarūpaṃ pāpakammaṃ na kareyyaṃ gārayhaṃ upavajjan’ti.
an4.244:4.9.eng: There’s no way I’d ever do such a bad and reprehensible deed, deserving of criticism.’

an4.244:4.10.pli: Evamevaṃ kho, bhikkhave, yassa kassaci bhikkhussa vā bhikkhuniyā vā evaṃ tibbā bhayasaññā paccupaṭṭhitā hoti pāṭidesanīyesu dhammesu, tassetaṃ pāṭikaṅkhaṃ—anāpanno vā pāṭidesanīyaṃ dhammaṃ na āpajjissati, āpanno vā pāṭidesanīyaṃ dhammaṃ yathādhammaṃ paṭikarissati.
an4.244:4.10.eng: In the same way, take any monk or nun who has set up such an acute perception of peril regarding confessable offenses. It can be expected that if they haven’t committed an confessable offense they won’t, and if they committed one they will deal with it properly.

an4.244:4.11.eng: These are the four perils of offenses.”
